greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Pi = Sum_{n >= 0} a(n)/n!.
comment: The current name does not define a(n) without ambiguity. It is meant that for each n, a(n) is the largest integer such that the remainder of Pi - (partial sum up to n) remains positive. This leads to the FORMULA given below. - _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 20 2017
reference: N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
link: Hans Havermann, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
Index entries for sequences related to the number Pi
formula: a(n) = floor(n!*Pi) - n*floor((n-1)!*Pi) for all n > 0. - _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 20 2017
mathematica: p = N[Pi, 1000]; Do[k = Floor[p*n! ]; p = p - k/n!; Print[k], {n, 0, 75} ]
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, _Robert G. Wilson v_
